posts.html:
About OpenCRVS

Open Civil Registration and Vital Statistics (OpenCRVS) is an open source system supporting the digitization of common processes for civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS). It captures information regarding the major events of the lives of citizens including birth, death, marriage, divorce, adoption and migration. DSi is working with Plan International Bangladesh as their development partner for the OpenCRVS software via a collaborative process using Agile methodology and shared tools and platforms. The Cabinet Division of Bangladesh is running this project.

Technical Challenge and Resolution

  • One of the major challenges we had faced when the application ran on low end devices. From the very beginning the application is developed as a progressing web application (PWA). We had to maintain device storage for maintaining a local database. For smooth operation, we had to do a lot of optimization while storing data.
  • The speciality of PWA is that the application can run offline. It can sync data with the server as soon as the device goes online. Since the application is running in rural areas with very low internet connectivity. Sometimes the application cannot sync with the server even if the device is online. We had to handle this special case by checking continuously if the application can reach the server.
  • The application needs to take some pictures of documents during the registration process. Considering the poor internet connectivity, we had to reduce the image quality so that the images could be uploaded without any issue. But we also had to consider the quality of the camera of low-end devices was very poor. This means reducing the quality of a low-quality image could create an unusable image. We had done a lot of image processing and image optimization mechanism based on the original image quality so that we could create a better output.
  • We had to integrate with the DHIS2 for fetching new born babies information for birth registration. The data of the DHIS2 did not follow the standard format, also the stability of the data was very poor. We had to check data availability using different logical checkpoints to make the data meaningful.
  • The system is used by the rural government officials and it needs to handle high volume of data. One of the important features is performance measurement and monitoring real time data. We have used time series databases, elastic search and similar technologies for those use cases.
  • We had to use Geocode for address structure. We had fetched the geocode list from the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics (BBS) server. We found that the BBS didn’t have any API for integration and it delivered the data in CSV and Excel format. As a result, we had to write services to fetch these data manually.
posts.plaintext:
About OpenCRVS

Open Civil Registration and Vital Statistics (OpenCRVS) is an open source system
supporting the digitization of common processes for civil registration and vital
statistics (CRVS). It captures information regarding the major events of the
lives of citizens including birth, death, marriage, divorce, adoption and
migration. DSi is working with Plan International Bangladesh as their
development partner for the OpenCRVS software via a collaborative process using
Agile methodology and shared tools and platforms. The Cabinet Division of
Bangladesh is running this project.

Technical Challenge and Resolution

 * One of the major challenges we had faced when the application ran on low end
   devices. From the very beginning the application is developed as a
   progressing web application (PWA). We had to maintain device storage for
   maintaining a local database. For smooth operation, we had to do a lot of
   optimization while storing data.
 * The speciality of PWA is that the application can run offline. It can sync
   data with the server as soon as the device goes online. Since the application
   is running in rural areas with very low internet connectivity. Sometimes the
   application cannot sync with the server even if the device is online. We had
   to handle this special case by checking continuously if the application can
   reach the server.
 * 
 * The application needs to take some pictures of documents during the
   registration process. Considering the poor internet connectivity, we had to
   reduce the image quality so that the images could be uploaded without any
   issue. But we also had to consider the quality of the camera of low-end
   devices was very poor. This means reducing the quality of a low-quality image
   could create an unusable image. We had done a lot of image processing and
   image optimization mechanism based on the original image quality so that we
   could create a better output.
 * 
 * We had to integrate with the DHIS2 for fetching new born babies information
   for birth registration. The data of the DHIS2 did not follow the standard
   format, also the stability of the data was very poor. We had to check data
   availability using different logical checkpoints to make the data meaningful.
 * The system is used by the rural government officials and it needs to handle
   high volume of data. One of the important features is performance measurement
   and monitoring real time data. We have used time series databases, elastic
   search and similar technologies for those use cases.
 * 
 * We had to use Geocode for address structure. We had fetched the geocode list
   from the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics (BBS) server. We found that the BBS
   didn’t have any API for integration and it delivered the data in CSV and
   Excel format. As a result, we had to write services to fetch these data
   manually.
posts.custom_excerpt: A Civil Registration and Vital Statistics (CRVS) system records the details of the major life events. Existing paper-based systems are insufficient, leaving large parts of the population unregistered and unprotected. The OpenCRVS system helps digitize the manual processes for CRVS for Bangladesh.

posts.html:
About ISDP
Integrated Service Delivery Platform (ISDP) is a project of the government of Bangladesh funded by UNDP. The ISDP project aims to connect 2800+ government digital services in a central hub, easing interoperability between the e-services. With ISDP, organizations will find that they can share and collect more information from other services that were previously difficult, costly and time consuming to compile non-electronically. In addition to integrating government e-services ISDP will perform eligibility verification, provide notification of services delivery and create a running narrative of the citizens life.

Technical Challenges and Resolution
Handling the scale of data that ISDP will receive is a major challenge. Bangladesh is a large country with 170+ million people. The government already has more than a hundred digital services. There are plans to provide more than 2,800 digital services within a few years. The ISDP platform will be notified at each important step of receiving a digitalized service by a citizen. It has to meet the current rate of receiving data and has to scale up in the near future.
To handle the large influx of data, the ISDP has a queue-based data ingestion mechanism. The queue used is Apache Kafka. After the initial ingestion of data, it is processed with various microservices in an asynchronous fashion. Most of the microservices in ISDP are written in Node.js taking full advantage of its asynchronous execution model. A few of the microservices are written in Java using the Spring Framework. All microservices are run in Docker containers. The whole system runs on Kubernetes. The combination of Kubernetes, Docker, Kafka and the microservice architecture allows the system to be easily scalable as needed.
posts.plaintext:
About ISDP
Integrated Service Delivery Platform (ISDP) is a project of the government of
Bangladesh funded by UNDP. The ISDP project aims to connect 2800+ government
digital services in a central hub, easing interoperability between the
e-services. With ISDP, organizations will find that they can share and collect
more information from other services that were previously difficult, costly and
time consuming to compile non-electronically. In addition to integrating
government e-services ISDP will perform eligibility verification, provide
notification of services delivery and create a running narrative of the citizens
life.



Technical Challenges and Resolution
Handling the scale of data that ISDP will receive is a major challenge.
Bangladesh is a large country with 170+ million people. The government already
has more than a hundred digital services. There are plans to provide more than
2,800 digital services within a few years. The ISDP platform will be notified at
each important step of receiving a digitalized service by a citizen. It has to
meet the current rate of receiving data and has to scale up in the near future.
To handle the large influx of data, the ISDP has a queue-based data ingestion
mechanism. The queue used is Apache Kafka. After the initial ingestion of data,
it is processed with various microservices in an asynchronous fashion. Most of
the microservices in ISDP are written in Node.js taking full advantage of its
asynchronous execution model. A few of the microservices are written in Java
using the Spring Framework. All microservices are run in Docker containers. The
whole system runs on Kubernetes. The combination of Kubernetes, Docker, Kafka
and the microservice architecture allows the system to be easily scalable as
needed.
posts.custom_excerpt: Integrated Service Delivery Platform (ISDP) aims to connect the public digital services to a central hub for the citizens. Getting all the information of a citizen in one place is the main objective of ISDP which will not only save time and cost but also accelerate the nation’s digitizing process.

posts.html:
About InfoIMAGE
InfoIMAGE provides online banking solutions to over 200 financial institutions throughout the US including banks, credit unions, mortgage, and utility companies. Its services include integrated print, electronic document management services, digital document ecosystem, electronic signature & secure digital workflow, and highly targeted data driven marketing and personalized business communication. DSi has been working as an offshore development partner of InfoIMAGE since 2013. Our team of more than 40 software engineers help provide an integrated statement portal, online creation & management of statements across multiple platforms, paper & electronic document management of notices, taxes, loans, online document exchange for signature approvals & e-payment services of online loan remittance, etc.

To assure the customers that its data center operations meet a certain level of quality, the production and staging environment has successfully completed e.g. SOC2 and SOC3 audits which focus on controls related to security, availability, confidentiality, processing integrity and privacy—validating that the system is protected against unauthorized physical and logical access.

Technical Challenges and Resolution

• Versatile Product Suit: Electronic document management system, Advanced Multi-Channel Marketing Solutions, Embedded Payment Solutions

• Working as an offshore team: Development process that suits DSi employees situated in 4 different countries. Large distributed scrum projects. Surveillance in common hours.

• Security: To assure the customers that its data center operations meet a certain level of quality, the production and staging environment has successfully completed e.g. SOC2 and SOC3 audits which focus on controls related to security, availability, confidentiality, processing integrity and privacy—validating that the system is protected against unauthorized physical and logical access.

• Multi-tenant: Personalized workflow for massive client base consisting around 180 banks and credit unions.

• Reliable. Resilient. Fail-over: Utmost priority to make the devops engineering processes automatic, immediate, and reliable.

• Long running development-partnership: Constant refactoring of maintainability workloads. Periodical surge in work-hours, for example, working in US timezone office hours during the tax season in January.

posts.html:
About Jenzabar Higher Reach
Jenzabar Higher Reach is a CRM for continuing education. Jenzabar, Inc. is a leading provider of enterprise software and services developed exclusively for higher education. The system provides a 360-degree view of student experience from recruitment to billing, to ensure student success. Jenzabar is the trusted partner of choice to more than 1,350 campuses worldwide, including private liberal arts, state, and community colleges and business, medical, law and other graduate schools. DSi has been working as the software development partner of Jenzabar for over 7 years. DSi developed a wide range of modules for Jenzabar and integrated Jenzabar Higher Reach CRM and Salesforce with the Higher Reach database. Clients of Jenzabar include over 400 universities. During pick time the system can support more than a million concurrent users.
Higher Reach allows students to select and purchase their courses by themselves beside all other back office functionalities. During peak seasons handling a large number purchase request was really challenging. In-order to handle this large number of requests and ensure a smooth payment gateway integration, we have developed our own request model framework which ensures the ability to accept 5K+ parallel requests and complete visibility and management of payment gateway integration. As part of this project, we have successfully integrated Higher Reach with 12+ payment gateways. During the peak season, more than 1 million students register in the system over a short period of time.

Technical Challenge and Resolution
Higher Reach allows students to select and purchase their courses by themselves beside all other back office functionalities. During peak seasons handling a large number purchase request was really challenging. In-order to handle this large number of requests and ensure a smooth payment gateway integration, we have developed our own request model framework which ensures the ability to accept 5K+ parallel requests and complete visibility and management of payment gateway integration. As part of this project, we have successfully integrated Higher Reach with 12+ payment gateways. During the peak season, more than 1 million students register in the system over a short period of time.

Higher Reach offers different types of modules to its clients. Among them, one of the major modules was the Corporate Training Module. CT module was fully developed on Amazon Web Services and currently available as SaaS. This module is divided into lots of microservices. Each microservice is written in a custom java framework and then ported into AWS platform as AWS Lambda Functions. We have used Amazon API Gateway to expose the rest services for each of these microservices. To ensure secure and smooth communication among the services, we have developed our own ENS (event notification system) framework using Amazon SNS and Amazon SQS services. Client end for this module was developed using AngularJS.

Many languages and frameworks are used throughout this project. The primary language is Java. AWS Lambda is heavily used. Node.js and React.js are also used in newer code. For the database backend, Oracle is heavily used along with Microsoft SQL Server and MySQL. The database size easily goes over a few hundred million rows during the peak seasons. There is significant integration with Salesforce using Salesforce Apex.

About Jenzabar Higher Reach
Jenzabar Higher Reach is a CRM for continuing education. Jenzabar, Inc. is a
leading provider of enterprise software and services developed exclusively for
higher education. The system provides a 360-degree view of student experience
from recruitment to billing, to ensure student success. Jenzabar is the trusted
partner of choice to more than 1,350 campuses worldwide, including private
liberal arts, state, and community colleges and business, medical, law and other
graduate schools. DSi has been working as the software development partner of
Jenzabar for over 7 years. DSi developed a wide range of modules for Jenzabar
and integrated Jenzabar Higher Reach CRM and Salesforce with the Higher Reach
database. Clients of Jenzabar include over 400 universities. During pick time
the system can support more than a million concurrent users.
Higher Reach allows students to select and purchase their courses by themselves
beside all other back office functionalities. During peak seasons handling a
large number purchase request was really challenging. In-order to handle this
large number of requests and ensure a smooth payment gateway integration, we
have developed our own request model framework which ensures the ability to
accept 5K+ parallel requests and complete visibility and management of payment
gateway integration. As part of this project, we have successfully integrated
Higher Reach with 12+ payment gateways. During the peak season, more than 1
million students register in the system over a short period of time.





Technical Challenge and Resolution
Higher Reach allows students to select and purchase their courses by themselves
beside all other back office functionalities. During peak seasons handling a
large number purchase request was really challenging. In-order to handle this
large number of requests and ensure a smooth payment gateway integration, we
have developed our own request model framework which ensures the ability to
accept 5K+ parallel requests and complete visibility and management of payment
gateway integration. As part of this project, we have successfully integrated
Higher Reach with 12+ payment gateways. During the peak season, more than 1
million students register in the system over a short period of time.

A high-level CT module’s backend architecture using AWS cloud platform

Higher Reach offers different types of modules to its clients. Among them, one
of the major modules was the Corporate Training Module. CT module was fully
developed on Amazon Web Services and currently available as SaaS. This module is
divided into lots of microservices. Each microservice is written in a custom
java framework and then ported into AWS platform as AWS Lambda Functions. We
have used Amazon API Gateway to expose the rest services for each of these
microservices. To ensure secure and smooth communication among the services, we
have developed our own ENS (event notification system) framework using Amazon
SNS and Amazon SQS services. Client end for this module was developed using
AngularJS.



Many languages and frameworks are used throughout this project. The primary
language is Java. AWS Lambda is heavily used. Node.js and React.js are also used
in newer code. For the database backend, Oracle is heavily used along with
Microsoft SQL Server and MySQL. The database size easily goes over a few hundred
million rows during the peak seasons. There is significant integration with
Salesforce using Salesforce Apex.
posts.custom_excerpt: Since 2013, DSi has been proudly working on a state-of-the-art, cloud-ready platform called Continuing Higher Education Management System as a development partner of Jenzabar, a leading name in higher education software solutions.

posts.html:
Docker container image is a lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, system tools, system libraries and settings.

Container images become containers at runtime and in the case of Docker containers – images become containers when they run on Docker Engine.

To understand you can think of an image is a snapshot of a container. That means, an image is read only system where everything is packaged for running an application. where container is an instance of that image.

To create a container, we can execute docker run command. like

$ docker run hello-world

By this command we’ve created a new container from “hello-world” image. If you want to see all the running containers, run this command

$ docker ps

You will see something like this

$ docker ps

CONTAINER ID  IMAGE   COMMAND     CREATED     STATUS     PORTS       NAMES

There’s no container! But we just ran a container, what happened to that, right?

Hang on a moment. I’m here to explain. But before that run this command

$ docker ps -a

Now, you can see that container. Here you can see an auto generated container ID. The image the container is created from. The status is exited, for this container. That means the container ran but after executing the application, the application is exited. Container had nothing to execute so, docker is smart enough to stop the container as well. At last you can see NAMES for our container. The name is also automatically generated by docker. But we can specify our container name by ourselves. To do that we have to pass --name flag

$ docker run --name my-hello-world-container hello-world

Enough hello-world example. Let’s see something useful in our real life.

Running Tomcat in Docker

Let’s run Apache tomcat in docker container. If you search in docker hub for tomcat. You’ll see that there are bunch of image under tomcat repository. A repository is a collection of images. Like tomcat:latest, tomcat:jdk11-corretto, tomcat:jdk11-openjdk-slim. Here tomcat is the repository and after each colon(:) it’s the tag name. For keeping commands clean for now, I’m just using the latest tag.

$ docker run --name my-tomcat tomcat

You can see from the terminal that tomcat is running on port 8080. Now if you go to your browser and hit localhost:8080. You will see “This site can’t be reached”. That means nothing is running on port 8080!

I told you earlier, docker container runs on totally isolated environment. You’re trying to access your host machine’s 8080 port. But tomcat is running on my-tomcat container. So, you cannot access that like this. But there is a way, it calls PORT binding. You can bind your host machine port with container port by publishing port from container. To publish port you can add --publish or just -p flag when running the container.

$ docker run -p 8080:8080 --name my-another-tomcat tomcat

Now if you go to localhost:8080 you can see that tomcat is running.

posts.html:
When I first heard about docker two questions came to my mind.

  • What is Docker?
  • Why Docker?

If I start explaining what is Docker, it probably won’t be understandable at first. So, just for now just imagine it’s a magic box. Bear with me till the end of this course I hope you’ll love this magic box.

But now let’s start by answering the question – why docker?

May be in the middle of the night you woke up seeing a dream of million dollar idea and decided to write the application right away. The application has some life cycle. First you have to build the application, then run it, then distribute it then you need to maintain or manage the application.

You decided to write the application but you’ve some dependencies for that like language, dbs, servers, tools etc.

Let’s just imagine you’ll be needing these following technologies to build your application

  • JDK (v1.8)
  • Maven ( 3.6.2)
  • Apache Tomcat (v8.5.47)
  • Redis (v5.0.6)
  • MySQL (v8.0.18)
  • MongoDB 4.2.1

You started installing each of those in your system. But CRAP!! You might have faced something like this scenario.

Sometimes or should I say most of the times running an installer leads to an error. You troubleshoot it, then re run it and then get another error. Again troubleshoot it and re-run. And may be finally doing these steps a few times you successfully install the dependency in your system. But in the meantime, you’ve successfully wasted 8-10 hours just for creating a development environment in your computer. Phew.. Finally you started actual coding.

May be after developing some modules you decided to hire 3 more people for your project.

And guess what! Each of them started by doing installing the dependencies. And they need to setup the exact same version of your environment. Maybe they already had installed some of the dependencies with older version. It will conflict with the newer version. At the end each of them waste some amounts of times just for getting their environment ready. What a shameful way of wasting time!!

Each of the team members need exact same version of every tools and technologies

If you can relate this with yourself, don’t be sad, you’re not alone. Most of the developer has faced these issues in their lifetime.

If I say with the help of docker you’ll never face something like this ever! Yes you heard me right. You just need docker installed in you machine and then docker guarantees you will never see something like this ever in your life.

You just say something like this

docker run mongo

But is this the only reason why you’ll use docker? Probably not. It’s something you get from docker out of the box, it’s really helpful for a developer but there are other tools as well for doing just this. There are much greater reason for using docker. And we’ll talk about that in the next lesson.

posts.html:
Building Your Spring Boot Application Run the following command inside your application’s root directory:

mvn clean package

The executable JAR file is now available in the target directory. By executing the following command on the command line we can run the application

java -jar my-spring-boot-app-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar

But the application is now running on foreground. So you might want to run it in detached mode or as a background process. So you might add an & at the end of the earlier command. In this way process goes into background and your terminal is free. But is it a good way of running your application?

The answer is No. You might want to see your spring standard output logs or store it somewhere. Also you may need to restart the application. Or you might need to restart the server and when the server is up again you want your application to startup automatically.

For this in mind, you might need to write a systemd service on linux. What is a systemd service?

A unit configuration file whose name ends in “.service” encodes information about a process controlled and supervised by systemd.

With the power of systemd service gives you much more control over your application startup.

Before creating the service let’s copy our application to this directory /usr/local/applications/my-spring-boot-app/. This could be any directory. It’s totally your choice. But make sure the user who runs the application has the proper permissions. For Linux group and user permissions in mind. Let’s create a user and a group just for deploying the application. I’ll be creating a user and a group with the same name spring. It can be any name you want.

sudo mkdir /usr/local/applications
sudo useradd -U -d /usr/local/applications -M -s /bin/false spring
sudo chown -R spring:spring /usr/local/applications

Our .jar is placed where we wanted. Let’s now write a systemd service for our spring boot application.

Run the following command to create a service named my-spring-boot-app.service. All the service ends with a .service extension

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/my-spring-boot-app.service

Now put the following contents into the file

[Unit]
Description=A Spring Boot application
After=syslog.target

[Service]
User=spring
Group=spring

ExecStart=/usr/bin/java -jar /usr/local/applications/my-spring-boot-app-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar
SuccessExitStatus=143

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Next, reload the systemd daemon using the following command:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload

Start the application using the following command:

sudo systemctl start my-spring-boot-app.service

To check the status of the application run the following command:

sudo systemctl status my-spring-boot-app.service

If you want to see the logs output of the service, you can you journalctl

sudo journalctl -u my-spring-boot-app.service -f

-u , --unit is to specify the systemd unit

-f, --follow to show the most recent entries

sudo mkdir /usr/local/applications
sudo useradd -U -d /usr/local/applications -M -s /bin/false spring
sudo chown -R spring:spring /usr/local/applications


Our .jar is placed where we wanted. Let’s now write a systemd service for our
spring boot application.

Run the following command to create a service named my-spring-boot-app.service.
All the service ends with a .service extension

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/my-spring-boot-app.service


Now put the following contents into the file

[Unit]
Description=A Spring Boot application
After=syslog.target

[Service]
User=spring
Group=spring

ExecStart=/usr/bin/java -jar /usr/local/applications/my-spring-boot-app-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar
SuccessExitStatus=143

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target


Next, reload the systemd daemon using the following command:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload


Start the application using the following command:

sudo systemctl start my-spring-boot-app.service


To check the status of the application run the following command:

sudo systemctl status my-spring-boot-app.service


If you want to see the logs output of the service, you can you journalctl

sudo journalctl -u my-spring-boot-app.service -f


-u , --unit is to specify the systemd unit

-f, --follow to show the most recent entries

posts.html:
I found my passion in programming during my high school days. Started a formal career as a Systems Administrator and Developer in leading ISP of the day, Agni Systems Ltd. in 1999. Designed and implemented one of the largest pre-paid billing systems for dial-up subscribers and helped Agni to become one of the largest dial-up ISPs with multiple POPs in the country.

With Tanveer Hasan and Mushtaque Ahmed, we founded DSi in 2001 focusing on doing high end software development projects for a world wide clientele. Joined Therap Services in 2004. As its lead developer and later on CTO, I helped the company to grow from its pilot to phase until it became a national leader in its niche segment in the health sector in USA.

With my experience and natural abilities, my primary strengths have become developing large and scalable systems and building the right teams that can build such systems.

After a successful career at Therap Services, I joined a Y-Combinator funded startup, Backpack Technologies. Helped to stabilize their back-end and scale it.

I rejoined DSi full time in 2017. DSi has the 2nd largest team of Enterprise Java programmers in Bangladesh working for clients in USA and Europe. Leveraging the highly skilled workforce of DSi, my current goal is to transform the company to the next stage where we can serve the growing needs of the IT sector of the country with high end, complex and scalable systems to improve the lives of millions.

Education Background

BSc. in Electrical and Electronic Engineering (EEE) from Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology.

After a successful career at Therap Services, I joined a Y-Combinator funded startup, Backpack Technologies. Helped to stabilize their back-end and scale it.

I rejoined DSi full time in 2017. DSi has the 2nd largest team of Enterprise Java programmers in Bangladesh working for clients in USA and Europe. Leveraging the highly skilled workforce of DSi, my current goal is to transform the company to the next stage where we can serve the growing needs of the IT sector of the country with high end, complex and scalable systems to improve the lives of millions.

posts.html:
Bulk (or batch) operations are used to perform an action on more than one resource in single request. This can help reduce networking overhead. For network performance it is usually better to make fewer requests instead of more requests with less data.

However, before adding support for bulk operations you should think twice if this feature is really needed. Often network performance is not what limits request throughput. You should also consider techniques like HTTP pipelining as alternative to improve performance.

When implementing bulk operations we should differentiate between two different cases:

  • Bulk operations that group together many arbitrary operations in one request. For example: Delete product with id 42, create a user named John and retrieve all product-reviews created yesterday.
  • Bulk operations that perform one operation on different resources of the same type. For example: Delete the products with id 23, 45, 67 and 89.

In the next section we will explore different solutions that can help us with both situations. Be aware that the shown solutions might not look very REST-like. Bulk operations in general are not very compatible with REST constraints as we operate on different resources with a single request. So there simply is no real REST solution.

In the following examples we will always return a synchronous response. However, as bulk operations usually take longer to process it is likely you are also interested in an asynchronous processing style. In this case, my post about asynchronous operations with REST might also be interesting to you.

Expressing multiple operations within the request body

Probably a way that comes to mind quickly is to use a standard data format like JSON to define a list of desired operations.

Let’s start with a simple example request:

1
POST /batch
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
[
    {
        "path": "/products",
        "method": "post",
        "body": {
            "name": "Cool Gadget",
            "price": "
1
nbsp;12.45 USD"         }     }, {         "path": "/users/43",         "method": "put",         "body": {             "name": "Paul"         }     },     ... ]

We use a generic /batch endpoint that accepts a simple JSON format to describe desired operations using URIs and HTTP methods. Here, we want to execute a POST request to /products and a PUT request to /users/43.

posts.html:
DSi takes great pride in announcing that one of our biggest national-scale projects Integrated Primary Education Management Information System (IPEMIS)  under Directorate of Primary Education (DPE) has finally been launched on 30 April, 2021. The ceremony was inaugurated by our Honorable State Minister of Primary and Mass Education Mr. Mohammad Zakir Hossain.

DSi was awarded this contract by UNICEF and the new system will manage data of over 2 crore students, 1.3 lac schools, and 3.5 lac teachers. DSi aims to integrate the existing internal and external systems, revamp areas like textbook distribution, teachers training, census, and add features like remote learning and result collection. The system will aid DPE significantly to make timely and effective decisions for the primary education sector of Bangladesh. We would like to give special thanks to UNICEF, ADB, DPE and DSi folks for their collaboration throughout the project.
posts.plaintext:
DSi takes great pride in announcing that one of our biggest national-scale
projects Integrated Primary Education Management Information System (IPEMIS)
 under Directorate of Primary Education (DPE) has finally been launched on 30
April, 2021. The ceremony was inaugurated by our Honorable State Minister of
Primary and Mass Education Mr. Mohammad Zakir Hossain.

DSi was awarded this contract by UNICEF and the new system will manage data of
over 2 crore students, 1.3 lac schools, and 3.5 lac teachers. DSi aims to
integrate the existing internal and external systems, revamp areas like textbook
distribution, teachers training, census, and add features like remote learning
and result collection. The system will aid DPE significantly to make timely and
effective decisions for the primary education sector of Bangladesh. We would
like to give special thanks to UNICEF, ADB, DPE and DSi folks for their
collaboration throughout the project.

posts.html:
This guide will give you idea about how to setup your post in Ghost so it will properly show up in the Website.

Tags

The first thing you need to know is the predefined tags. Tagging a post critical as Tag is the thing that decides where this post will show up in the website.

How to tag a post

There are couple of pre-defined tags available to you. The names are quite self explanatory. Say you are creating a news item, then you tag your post as "news".
Tag your post "project" if the post is about a project you want to show in the project section of the website.

There are two special tags that you can stack up to signify something special about a post.
1. featuredonhome - The DSi website features various post items on home page. To feature in item in a relative section on home page, add "featuredonhome" tag to that post.  

2. two-colum - Every post has it's own dedicated page on the website. By default the main contain of the post is shown in one column. Use "two-column" tag to show it in two column layout.

List of all tags

?????????????????????????????

Featured Image

????????????????????????????????????

Featuring an item

An item can be featured in two ways, 1) featured on Home page (which is discussed previously in Tag section), and 2) featured in corresponding item list pages.

To feature an item to to its corresponding list page, just simply check the "Feature this post" options as shown bellow -

Regular list item

All the post that are not marked as featured appears in regular list section on their corresponding pages.

** SPECIAL CASE: PEOPLE

For people regular list item, feature image is handled slightly differently for visual requirements. The default "Featured Image" (discussed Featured Image section) is not used in this case, instead we need to insert an image in main post with the caption "onRegularList". This will be used as cover image of the list item.

Note to Developer: To grab this image from a post, use the grabImageURLFromGhostPost(html, caption) function from utility.js. And to remove this image from the post, use removeImageFromGhostPost(html, caption)
posts.plaintext:
This guide will give you idea about how to setup your post in Ghost so it will
properly show up in the Website. 

Tags
The first thing you need to know is the predefined tags. Tagging a post critical
as Tag is the thing that decides where this post will show up in the website.

How to tag a post
There are couple of pre-defined tags available to you. The names are quite self
explanatory. Say you are creating a news item, then you tag your post as "news".
Tag your post "project" if the post is about a project you want to show in the
project section of the website.

There are two special tags that you can stack up to signify something special
about a post. 
1. featuredonhome - The DSi website features various post items on home page. To
feature in item in a relative section on home page, add "featuredonhome" tag to
that post.

2. two-colum - Every post has it's own dedicated page on the website. By default
the main contain of the post is shown in one column. Use "two-column" tag to
show it in two column layout.

List of all tags 
?????????????????????????????

Featured Image
????????????????????????????????????

Featuring an item
An item can be featured in two ways, 1) featured on Home page (which is
discussed previously in Tag section), and 2) featured in corresponding item list
pages. 

To feature an item to to its corresponding list page, just simply check the
"Feature this post" options as shown bellow - 

Regular list item
All the post that are not marked as featured appears in regular list section on
their corresponding pages. 

** SPECIAL CASE: PEOPLE

For people regular list item, feature image is handled slightly differently for
visual requirements. The default "Featured Image" (discussed Featured Image
section) is not used in this case, instead we need to insert an image in main
post with the caption "onRegularList". This will be used as cover image of the
list item.

> Note to Developer: To grab this image from a post, use the
grabImageURLFromGhostPost(html, caption) function from utility.js. And to remove
this image from the post, use removeImageFromGhostPost(html, caption)

posts.html:
National Scale Government Project

Integrated Service Delivery Platform (ISDP) is a project of the Government of Bangladesh funded by UNDP and governed by a2i. This integrated platform has been designed to connect 2800+ government digital services in a central hub, easing interoperability between the government e-services of Bangladesh. With ISDP, organizations will find that they can share and collect more information from other connected services that were previously difficult, costly, and time-consuming to compile non-electronically. In addition to integrating government e-services, ISDP has the capability to perform eligibility verification, provide notification of services delivery and create a running narrative of the citizens’ life.

Key Features

  • Facilitates Easy Enrollment in Services Through Auto-filling Citizen Data Using their NID/UID
  • Cross Organization Data Verification
  • Eligibility Verification for Social Safety Net Services
  • Record Service Delivery Notification
  • Provides API Hub for Digital Services for Sharing Data with Each Other
  • Nationwide Service Delivery Analytics

posts.html:
Project for Special Security Force (SSF), Government of Bangladesh


DSi developed a Secured Communication Platform for SSF to establish end-to-end encrypted internal communication between agents and their reporting entities. This highly secure communication application suite includes a web-based system and mobile applications for both Android and iOS devices.

The Special Security Force (SSF) is a Bangladeshi law enforcement agency that provides security services to government officials and foreign dignitaries. SSF aims to provide physical security to the President and Prime Minister of Bangladesh, and any person designated as a very important person (VIP) by the Government of Bangladesh.

Key Features

• Mobile applications for both iOS and Android
• Web based administrator portal
• Secure messaging
• End-to-end encryption

posts.html:
Document Management System

DSi has been the developing partner of Legility, a proprietary web-based document management and review repository designed for contract attorneys and paralegals in the United States. Recenseo is Legility's complete review solution. This system helps lawyers and law firms organize and sort through millions of text documents to find relevant information. The software is a powerful utility built on top of a highly intuitive, secure, and stable Java-based infrastructure that is easy to access from virtually anywhere. The solution includes a robust machine-learning data analytics framework facilitating faster and easy-to-use document review for users. Clients of Legility include AMLAW 100 Firms, Fortune 50 Companies, eDiscovery Service Providers, Small Law Firms, Small Businesses, and Corporate Alliance Customers.

Major Clients

• Texas Instruments
• Susman Godfrey LLP
• Alston & Bird
• Altisource Solutions Inc.
• Expedia Inc.
• Jones Day

posts.html:
National Scale Project for the Directorate of Primary Education (DPE)

The Integrated Primary Educational Management Information System (IPEMIS) project is being developed for the Directorate of Primary Education (DPE), funded by UNICEF and ADB. This national scale project will manage data of over 2 crore students, 1.3 lac schools, and 3.5 lac teachers. DSi aims to integrate the existing internal and external systems, revamp areas like textbook distribution, teachers training, census, and add features like remote learning and result collection. The system will aid DPE significantly to make timely and effective decisions for the primary education sector of Bangladesh.

Key Features

  • School module
  • Teachers and Staff module
  • Student module
  • Census Survey module
  • Book Distribution module
  • Monitoring
  • Teacher's Training module with LMS PECE Result Collection
  • Remote learning module

posts.custom_excerpt: This national-scale project is being built to manage data of over 2 crore students, 1.3 lac schools, and 3.5 lac teachers of the country. DSi takes pride in realizing the nation’s first-ever attempt to digitize the primary education system on such a mass scale.

posts.title: Teacher Transfer Management System (TTMS)

Teacher Transfer Management System (TTMS) aims to revolutionize government primary school teachers’ transfer application experience for over 400,000 teachers. The system will digitize, automate, and eventually replace the existing manual application process. Once operational, this system will give the teachers hassle-free, corruption-free, direct access to apply and track their transfer application status. When an application is made online, TTMS will manage the entire life-cycle of a transfer application centrally. An admin can see the vacancies in respective locations, teachers transferred, teachers joined, applications pending, and other details. The application will be processed, maintaining the hierarchy of school administration."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Key Features"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"Managing transfer application life- cycle"]],[[0,[],0,"Application tracking within upazila, district, division"]],[[0,[],0,"Powerful dashboard with location-wise application tracking"]],[[0,[],0,"Application auto forward if unattended"]],[[0,[],0,"Transfer session control management"]],[[0,[],0,"Transfer order creation and distribution System generated application prioritization"]],[[0,[],0,"SMS notification for approval/rejection Multiple validation for application submission"]],[[0,[],0,"Auto application review process in a fixed time frame"]]]],[1,"p",[]]],"ghostVersion":"4.0"}
posts.html:
National Scale Project for the Directorate of Primary Education (DPE)

DSi has developed the Teacher Transfer Management System (TTMS) under the supervision of the Directorate of Primary Education (DPE). Teacher Transfer Management System (TTMS) aims to revolutionize government primary school teachers’ transfer application experience for over 400,000 teachers. The system will digitize, automate, and eventually replace the existing manual application process. Once operational, this system will give the teachers hassle-free, corruption-free, direct access to apply and track their transfer application status. When an application is made online, TTMS will manage the entire life-cycle of a transfer application centrally. An admin can see the vacancies in respective locations, teachers transferred, teachers joined, applications pending, and other details. The application will be processed, maintaining the hierarchy of school administration.

Key Features

  • Managing transfer application life- cycle
  • Application tracking within upazila, district, division
  • Powerful dashboard with location-wise application tracking
  • Application auto forward if unattended
  • Transfer session control management
  • Transfer order creation and distribution System generated application prioritization
  • SMS notification for approval/rejection Multiple validation for application submission
  • Auto application review process in a fixed time frame

posts.html:
DSi takes extreme pride in the successful integration of the National Health System (DHIS2) with the Civil Registration and Vital Statistics System (OpenCRVS) initiated by the Cabinet Division of Bangladesh Government and Plan International. Narsingdi Sadar Hospital now has the birth registration process in place to automatically initiate the registration and certification process after every birth in the hospital.  This is a major step forward towards our government’s ultimate goal of ensuring 100% birth registration within 45 days. This system aims to manage data of major vital statistics of 17 crore people of Bangladesh in the near future.

OpenCRVS is now also available as a digital public good for civil registration! See www.github.com/opencrvs/opencrvs-core for source-code and info on how to deploy, configure and customize for the country context. Designed for low resource settings, OpenCRVS provides governments with a user-centric, rights-based and fully interoperable civil registration solution that can be deployed, operated and maintained by local teams.

Thanks to collaborating partners Plan International, Jembi Health Systems, Vital Strategies, Digital Impact Alliance (DIAL) at the United Nations Foundation and PATH on their vision to ensure that every individual on the planet is recognized, protected and provided for from birth.

Read Bandana Rani's story here.

Recently, Bandana Rani gave birth to twins at Narsingdi Sadar Hospital. She is the first mother for whom the birth registration process of her twins started from the hospital without any hassle as soon as they were born. In this process, the parents of the twins will easily get the birth registration certificate of the child as soon as they go to Narsingdi Municipality with the required documents.

Plan International Bangladesh's pilot project Civil Registration and Vital Statistics-OpenCRVS is an open source digital CRVS solution that makes the birth and death registration process quick and easy. OpenCRVS has been able to establish an interconnection with Bangladesh's "Hospital Health Management System" (DHIS2). This interconnected, secure and modern system is a groundbreaking step towards bringing government services to the doorsteps of citizens.

Reference:

https://www.facebook.com/planinbangladesh/photos/a.378697962178894/3352800781435249?type=3

This system aims to manage data of major vital statistics of 17 crore people of

See www.github.com/opencrvs/opencrvs-core
[https://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.github.com%2Fopencrvs%2Fopencrvs-core%3Ffbclid%3DIwAR2u4RiO3VAC6b5WjUoG4EK3IJdJcBb4VmtiGDqwdGJT-l-pwLd-zfZthbs&h=AT1M93Yjo5sHk6E-vPb_wa4AErvbgQD3-Po5hPzX8XyaUKpNAs8EhazNIL81-B5a-tWtvZmTNHmoBKhACM3kwy1aSRhq05syaauxA_dnV5ldGEV-zTKCzF4FjsLxwJI-tA&__tn__=-UK-R&c[0]=AT2WXFjaeZfsxh5pVIYkXEZA3C9CRB_dY3ZzLGvSLZ2Ipy8Zy1X4NWmAWdIUHwsYz87GAi_wXGFwSwUQr2rWjaKjsW3c1pvCOFMGQGuOdgcguFr-HFn414nipwgR0-oIAl_NYbK2CX9qVXCPnMUTuvuMLgS88aY89jUu5X3GKG--z3qmlKI-wUCmONfEKyMTmr8_6XU] 
for source-code and info on how to deploy, configure and customize for the
country context. Designed for low resource settings, OpenCRVS provides
governments with a user-centric, rights-based and fully interoperable civil
registration solution that can be deployed, operated and maintained by local
teams.

Thanks to collaborating partners Plan International, Jembi Health Systems, Vital
Strategies, Digital Impact Alliance (DIAL) at the United Nations Foundation and
PATH on their vision to ensure that every individual on the planet is
recognized, protected and provided for from birth.

Read Bandana Rani's story here.

Recently, Bandana Rani gave birth to twins at Narsingdi Sadar Hospital. She is
the first mother for whom the birth registration process of her twins started
from the hospital without any hassle as soon as they were born. In this process,
the parents of the twins will easily get the birth registration certificate of
the child as soon as they go to Narsingdi Municipality with the required
documents.

Plan International Bangladesh's pilot project Civil Registration and Vital
Statistics-OpenCRVS is an open source digital CRVS solution that makes the birth
and death registration process quick and easy. OpenCRVS has been able to
establish an interconnection with Bangladesh's "Hospital Health Management
System" (DHIS2). This interconnected, secure and modern system is a
groundbreaking step towards bringing government services to the doorsteps of
citizens.

Reference:

https://www.facebook.com/planinbangladesh/photos/a.378697962178894/3352800781435249?type=3
posts.custom_excerpt: DSi takes extreme pride in the successful integration of the National Health System (DHIS2) with OpenCRVS. Narsingdi Sadar Hospital now has the birth registration process in place to automatically initiate the registration and certification process after every birth in the hospital.

posts.html:
For those who are designing long forms that have more than 7 questions, this article is for you. Here is a guide to help you build better long format forms, applications, or information requests.

Making online forms should be more than just taking a paper form and making it digital. Digitizing a paper form comes with additional complications that have to be accounted for because some things just don’t directly translate. But the upside of digitizing a paper form means that you can add some sweet logic and improve the interaction experience for the person filling it out.

The first thing you will want to do is gather insights to inform your design. You do this by interviewing a selection of the people who fill out the form and people who process the form. These insights are critical for removing questions, adding questions, or rewriting them. Then make a list of all of the questions that you intend on asking in your online form.

For really long forms with many questions, here are seven things that you can try:

1. Group your questions into sections

Sort your questions into manageable chunks. When you have a long form you are likely asking questions across many different themes. Your goal is to identify what these themes are and sort your questions into easy to understand sections.

Once you have sections this means that you can more clearly map where a person is in their process of completing the form. Completing sections also allows for small rewards in a long and likely not fun form filling process.

2. Make location visible

With a paper form, you can scan the whole document before answering any questions. This means that the person filling out the form always know their location and can estimate how long it will take to finish.

A key difference between short forms and long forms is that they require a different user experience. Short forms are filled out in a couple of minutes, long forms can take hours — and it is expected that people will take breaks between sessions. For long forms, you need to include a “you are here” feature, that keeps the person orientated while also giving the ability to estimate how much time is remaining.

To make location visible, you want to show where the person filling out the form is in the process. You can use a percentage to complete icon, page numbers, bread-crumbs, loading bars, a stepper, etc. There is no standard go-to design for this, you’ll need to find a system that works with your form.

3. Don’t make questions out-of-focus

Only hide out-of-focus questions surrounding the in-focus question for very short forms. This design is good for a simple form like a survey but bad for long online forms with many questions.

When I fill out a form like this, I can feel my heart-rate rise because I’m trying to figure out if I’m being tricked into thinking the form is shorter than it really is.

This style of reducing the opacity for out-of-focus questions is not accessible. People will inevitably feel like they should read the out of focus text before it comes into focus. But, because the colours of the text on the screen does not meet contrast accessibility standards, the readability is reduced causing either difficulty for the person trying to read the out-of-focus question if they can even see it in the first place.

4. Use a stepper

Show all sections of the form at all times and show where the person is at in their journey to completion. Highlight the active section, show which sections are complete.

Numbering the questions that are in a section, allows for orientation. I can scroll to the bottom and see that there are 14 questions in this section then go back to the top and start working on the first question with knowledge and forecast about the amount of work ahead of me.

5. Set expectations before the start

To prepare the person for starting the form, give them as much context as possible. This will increase completion rates for individuals that start the process.

Questions an introduction could answer are:

  1. Why is the person is filling out this form?
  2. How long should it take to fill out the form?
  3. What is the timeline for the next steps?
  4. Do they need to prepare anything in advance (e.g. have a drivers license handy or prepare documents)?
  5. What happens to the information they provide? Who has access to it, how will it be used, how does it meet privacy standards?
  6. Does filling out the form cost money? Don’t surprise people at the end with the cost.

Other things that might be worth considering are:

  • Does the form autosave?
  • If they walk away or take a long time on a page, is it possible to lose all the information that they entered?
  • Who do people contact when they get stuck? Is that person different than technical support?

posts.html:
Project for Wolters Kluwer

Wolters Kluwer is a global provider of professional information, software solutions, and services for clinicians, accountants, lawyers, and tax, finance, audit, risk, compliance, and regulatory sectors. We worked with them to develop the compliance application approved by major banks in the United States. The system used Smart Data Mining to determine fraudulent behavior in the money transaction market.

Major Clients:

  • Bank of America
  • Citibank N.A.
  • J.P. Morgan Chase
posts.plaintext:
Project for Wolters Kluwer
Wolters Kluwer is a global provider of professional information, software
solutions, and services for clinicians, accountants, lawyers, and tax, finance,
audit, risk, compliance, and regulatory sectors. We worked with them to develop
the compliance application approved by major banks in the United States. The
system used Smart Data Mining to determine fraudulent behavior in the money
transaction market.

Major Clients:

 * Bank of America
 * Citibank N.A.
 * J.P. Morgan Chase
posts.custom_excerpt: DSi has been a longtime development partner of Wolters Kluwer, a leading global information services company.
